sub_topic: Ligand substitution reactions in coordination chemistry
message_1: What is the product formed when a solution of silver nitrate is added to a solution of potassium hexacyanoferrate(II)? Write the balanced equation for the reaction and explain the type of ligand substitution reaction that is occurring in this coordination chemistry reaction.
message_2:
When a solution of silver nitrate (AgNO3) is added to a solution of potassium hexacyanoferrate(II) (K4[Fe(CN)6]), a precipitation reaction occurs, forming silver hexacyanoferrate(II) (Ag4[Fe(CN)6]) and potassium nitrate (KNO3) as the products. The balanced equation for this reaction is:

4 AgNO3(aq) + K4[Fe(CN)6](aq) â†’ Ag4[Fe(CN)6](s) + 4 KNO3(aq)

In this reaction, a ligand substitution does not occur. Instead, a precipitation reaction takes place, where the silver ions (Ag+) from the silver nitrate solution and the hexacyanoferrate(II) complex anions [Fe(CN)6]4- from the potassium hexacyanoferrate(II) solution combine to form the insoluble silver hexacyanoferrate(II) precipitate. The remaining potassium ions (K+) and nitrate ions (NO3-) stay in the solution as potassium nitrate.
